text: You've done a great job exploring the various degrees of compactness. When you watch the  morph sequence where you take the factorial function from its most exploded graphical form and take it all the way to textual, my mind instantly becomes relieved at the textual form resulting. I think for people well trained in reading code, these graphical tools seem like a step in the wrong direction. However for those not yet trained to read code, i would imagine the graphical form holds appeal. I would caution you that one thing you are not exploring is the effect of the code on the state of the systems. In some sense it is the runtime environment that is of interest as it executes. So instead of spending so much time evaluating all the different levels of compactness, perhaps exploring the animation aspects of the program as it runs would be more fruitful.

Copy propagation in 150 LoC, noice!!
https://github.com/willcrichton/inliner/blob/master/inliner/passes/copy_propagation.py

text: Probably not surprising to anyone who knows me, but: I _love_ the idea of using compiler technology to help understand code rather than make it go fast. Output for humans rather than machines :heart:

elements.text: Probably not surprising to anyone who knows me, but: I
love
the idea of using compiler technology to help understand code rather than make it go fast. Output for humans rather than machines

text: When I first tried Scratch, I imagined it would just be a cute toy, tedious to actually use, so I was really surprised by how well it works.

elements.text: When I first tried Scratch, I imagined it would just be a cute toy, tedious to actually use, so I was really surprised by how well it works.

text: Yes, clojure.spec looks mighty interesting: typing the shape of data.  Historically though Haskell has a regular way to define data, defining classes so as to be derived genetically for all types has been clunky.

elements.text: Yes, clojure.spec looks mighty interesting: typing the shape of data.  Historically though Haskell has a regular way to define data, defining classes so as to be derived genetically for all types has been clunky.

text: Yes, I mean attached to a powerful language (Haskell), but hopefully it will make Haskell a bit easier to use. For instance, Glance has less syntax than Haskell, and Glance might make it easier to rename variables, have better autocomplete, enable bottom up programming, and visualize example values,  recursion, and in-lining.

text: You can also do a lot of type directed templating.  Function definitions by case and adding accumulation/context parameters come to mind.

elements.text: You can also do a lot of type directed templating.  Function definitions by case and adding accumulation/context parameters come to mind.

text:
Over the last year I've spent a lot of time outside my area of expertise, mining some seemingly unrelated fields for inspiring ideas that can be combined with what we try to do here. One particularly deep rabbit hole I fell into was linguistics. As I'm slowly climbing my way back up into our world, I started trying to put some of the insights I bring with me from down there into a blog series.

My goal is to make some of the concepts I learned about more accessible to us designing and developing software. I think there is a lot that can be useful for dreaming up and building a more humane and democratized future of programming.

I start with very basic stuff, and go slowly, so there isn't much yet. I also try to keep the posts short (500-1000 words, ~3-6 minutes reading time). There are three of them right now, and you can start here: <https://stefan-lesser.com/2019/12/06/structure-and-behavior/>

Would love to hear what you think. Thank you!

text: Oh!  A direction I went for a while.  If we had had the wide Web and corpus statistics like we do now, I might have stayed.  As is the only interesting things were transformational grammar and Montague semantics, I moved into Philosophy and Logic.

elements.text: Oh!  A direction I went for a while.  If we had had the wide Web and corpus statistics like we do now, I might have stayed.  As is the only interesting things were transformational grammar and Montague semantics, I moved into Philosophy and Logic.

text: <@UA14TGLTC> Maybe you can help me understand the _linguistics wars_ better… did you come across the generative grammar vs. semantics divide? I'm obviously totally new to the field and just had the opportunity to discuss this with one linguist, but it seems to me that Lakoff's work (what I'm mostly into) is still today considered quite controversial. Did you ever get into the cognitive side of things at all?

text: This was 20+ years ago.  Between serious corpora, FMRI, and machine learning, I cannot imagine I know anything currently relevant.

attachments.title: Brains, Meaning and Corpus Statistics
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Brains, Meaning and Corpus Statistics
attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="300" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/QbTf2nE3Lbw?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

elements.text: Here we are
.  Yes, ten years ago, well before the Deep Learning.

"The first is something we didn't know before, that neural codings of ideas, at least for concrete nouns, are remarkably similar in our different heads. They're not identical. We are different. But the amazing thing is that they're similar enough that these modeling procedure can extrapolate from one person to another.

"The second thing is that you can predict the neural activity in your brain when you think about a word based on how that word is used on the web. That's exactly what this model is doing. The input to this model is "how is this word used on the web" and the output of the model is the predicted neural activity. And it works. So, there's something fundamental about semantics that's captured in corpus statistics."
